description: Borrowed from Latin addictus, past participle of addīcō (“deliver; devote; surrender”), from ad- (“to, towards, at”) + dīcō (“say; declare”)

entries.meaning: A person who is addicted, especially to a harmful drug
examples: He is an addict when it comes to chocolate cookies.

verbs.description: addict (third-person singular simple present addicts, present participle addicting, simple past and past participle addicted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Ancient Rome) To deliver (someone or something) following a judicial decision. [from 16th c.]
(reflexive, now rare, archaic) To devote (oneself) to a given activity, occupation, thing etc. [from 16th c.]
(transitive, obsolete) To bind (a person or thing) to the service of something. [16th–18th c.]
(reflexive, obsolete) To devote or pledge (oneself) to a given person, cause etc. [16th–19th c.]
(transitive, now rare, archaic) To devote (one's mind, talent etc.) to a given activity, occupation, thing etc. [from 16th c.]
(transitive) To make (someone) become devoted to a given thing or activity; to cause to be addicted. [from 17th c.]
